Pore/Structural Features.Structure Type: Nanostructured porous material with ordered channels, integrated into a polyamide thin film layer, forming hydrophilic nanochannels and a thinner separation layer (~70 nm).

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Size exclusion and strong electrostatic repulsion (Donnan effect)

Other Information.Additional Info: High rejection (95.23%) due to synergistic effect of size exclusion and electrostatic repulsion.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Partial passage due to less effective size exclusion and electrostatic repulsion compared to Na2SO4

Other Information.Additional Info: Rejection is lower than Na2SO4, following the order Na2SO4 > MgCl2 > NaCl.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Significant passage due to minimal effective size exclusion and electrostatic repulsion

Other Information.Additional Info: Lowest rejection among the tested salts, following the order Na2SO4 > MgCl2 > NaCl.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Combined size sieving, hydrophobic interactions, and strong adsorption by COFs

Other Information.Additional Info: 98.3% rejection before COFs adsorption saturation. The membrane can be regenerated by ethanol washing to release adsorbed BPA.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Combined size sieving, hydrophobic interactions, and strong adsorption by COFs

Other Information.Additional Info: 99.1% rejection. Maintains stable rejection during long-term filtration tests due to larger size and effective capture.

Guest Molecules.Mechanism: Combined size sieving, strong electrostatic repulsion (due to negative charge), hydrophobic interactions, and strong adsorption by COFs

Other Information.Additional Info: 99.3% rejection. Maintains stable rejection during long-term filtration tests due to negative charge and effective capture.
The molecular weight cut-off (MWCO) of ~280 Da indicates that PEGs below this molecular weight pass more readily, while those above are largely rejected.

Sieving Mechanism: Multi-modal sieving involving size exclusion, electrostatic repulsion, hydrophobic interactions, and strong adsorption by incorporated covalent organic frameworks (COFs).

Experimental Validation.Method: Laboratory-scale crossflow membrane filtration setup, FTIR, XPS, SEM, AFM, Zeta potential measurements, MWCO evaluation using neutral PEGs, Long-term stability tests, HPLC for EDC quantification.
Experimental Validation.Performance Metrics: Water permeance: 17.14 L m−2 h−1 bar−1; Na2SO4 rejection: 95.23%; MWCO: ~280 Da; BPA rejection: 98.3%; BPAF rejection: 99.1%; SOPP rejection: 99.3%; Water/BPA-selectivity nearly four times higher than NF-blank membrane.

Other Information.Additional Info: Thin film nanocomposite (TFN) membrane formed by incorporating TPB-DMTP-COF into a polyamide (PA) layer via interfacial polymerization. COF nanofillers are uniformly deposited on a PES substrate, creating additional water pathways and reducing hydraulic resistance. Membrane is regenerable for extended use in wastewater treatment.
